issues.description: The problem statement requires a static method named acceptSupplyDelivery(String, int, int) to handle deliveries and update the shared stock (see UML and textual requirements). The solution implementation instead provides a static method named receiveDelivery(String, int, int). This name/signature mismatch is structural: students reading the solution or tests expecting acceptSupplyDelivery will be confused or may implement the wrong method name. The implemented behavior matches the specification, but the method name differs.
issues.suggested_fix: Align the method name in the solution with the problem specification. Rename the solution method receiveDelivery(...) to acceptSupplyDelivery(...), or add a static acceptSupplyDelivery(...) wrapper that delegates to receiveDelivery(...). This preserves the intended behavior while matching the API the problem statement and tests expect.

issues.description: The problem statement and the provided example code refer to a static SealSaloon method named acceptSupplyDelivery(String, int, int) (UML and descriptions). However, the solution implementation implements the same functionality under a different name: receiveDelivery(String, int, int). This inconsistent naming for the same conceptual operation (accepting a supply delivery and updating the shared stock) creates a mapping barrier: students reading the problem or the example Main will look for acceptSupplyDelivery but the solution's SealSaloon exposes receiveDelivery instead.
issues.suggested_fix: Use a single consistent name for the supply-delivery operation across all artifacts. Best fix: rename the solution method receiveDelivery(...) to acceptSupplyDelivery(String name, int price, int quantity) (keeping it static) and update any calls (e.g., Main) accordingly. Alternatively, if receiveDelivery is preferred, update the problem statement and example Main to reference receiveDelivery — but prefer aligning code to the UML/problem name to avoid student confusion.
